informal_statement: Find one pair of positive integers $a,b$ such that $ab(a+b)$ is not divisible by $7$, but $(a+b)^7-a^7-b^7$ is divisible by $7^7$.
informal_proof:
So we want $7 \nmid ab(a+b)$ and $7^7 | (a+b)^7-a^7-b^7 = 7ab(a+b)(a^2+ab+b^2)^2$, so we want $7^3 | a^2+ab+b^2$.
Now take e.g. $a=2,b=1$ and get $7|a^2+ab+b^2$. Now by some standard methods like Hensels Lemma (used to the polynomial $x^2+x+1$, so $b$ seen as constant from now) we get also some $\overline{a}$ with $7^3 | \overline{a}^2+\overline{a}b+b^2$ and $\overline{a} \equiv a \equiv 2 \mod 7$, so $7\nmid \overline{a}b(\overline{a}+b)$ and we are done. (in this case it gives $\overline{a}=325$)
formal_statement:
theorem imo_1984_p2:
  fixes a b :: nat
  assumes h0 : "0 < a \<and> 0 < b"
    and h1 : "\<not> (7 dvd a)"
    and h2 : "\<not> (7 dvd b)"
    and h3 : "\<not> (7 dvd (a+b))"
    and h4 : "(7^7) dvd ((a+b)^7 - a^7 - b^7)"
  shows "19 \<le> a + b"
